State of Michigan
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RICK SNYDER NICK LYON
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 31, 2018
Shelly Marner
Saginaw County DHHS
P O Box 5070
411 E. Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
RE: License #: CP630201395
P O Box 5070
411 E. Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
Dear Ms. Marner:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on August 20,
2018 thru August 23, 2018 and August 28, 2018. Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules, sections of the contract and requirements, a written corrective action plan
is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of
the Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan(ISEP) and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Services

Lansing, MI 48902

Facility Address: P O Box 5070
411 E. Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605

PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
Act 116 722.120
Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information;
availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department;
failure of licensee to cooperate with investigation,
inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care
and shall report to the department, when requested,
the facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and
subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives
are confidential and disclosure of this information shall
be properly safeguarded by the child care organization,
the department, and any other entity in possession of
the information.
Four of ten special investigation records reviewed showed
documentation of children protective service involvement in the
special evaluation, utilization of language such as CPS and MIC
was indicated, and in some cases the name of that CPS or MIC
person.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
4

Two of thirteen new employee records reviewed where the
employee’s position was governed by these rules, did not show
compliance:
One employee’s written probationary evaluation was not
documented, and the other was nine days late.
In five of five employee records reviewed where the employee
was employed over one-year, the record did not show
compliance:
Two records showed the employee’s annual evaluation was not
documented.
A third was over two months after the annual evaluation due
day; and a fourth and fifth was twenty-eight, and one hundred
fifty-three days late respectively.
R400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(1) An agency shall have a written foster parent/agency
agreement signed by the foster parent and the agency before
initially certifying a foster home for licensure.
One of six open foster home records reviewed did not show
documentation of a foster parent/agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and agency, as required by the rule.
R400.12324 Licensing recommendation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Two of six open foster home records reviewed showed the
licensing recommendation was not submitted to the department
at least 15 days before the respective foster home’s licensing
expiration date.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
5

One of ten special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation of submission of a special investigation record to
the licensing authority within 5 working days.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Six of ten special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation that a copy of the report was provided to social
services workers that had children placed in the home.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
Two of ten special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation all social services workers that had children
placed in the home were notified of the corrective action plan
and requirements for the foster parent.
R400.12328 Foster home record.
(2) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(d) a placement list of all children placed in the foster home,
including all of the following information about each child:
(iii) Date of, and reasons for, a child’s removal from the foster
home.
In two to three closed foster home records reviewed the
placement list did not document the date each child was
removal and the reason for the removal.
R400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in
R400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(g) Documentation of the child’s placement preparation.
6

Two of seven open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s preparation for placement.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
Three of six closed foster child records reviewed, and one of
two closed independent living youth records reviewed did not
show documentation of the child’s/youth’s preparation for the
change.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement.
(a) A summary of service provided during care up to the time of
the change in placement and the need that remain to be met
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Six of six closed foster child records reviewed, and two of two
closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s/youth’s needs that remain to be
met and provision for any continuing services.
R400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
7

Three of seven open foster child records reviewed did not show
document the foster parent was provided the information
identified in (c)-(h) before placement of the child.
A fourth and fifth foster child record was reviewed (due to a
foster parent reporting to the Division of Child Welfare Licensing
(DCWL) they were not informed of one foster child’s behavior
issues, and of another foster child being a bedwetter) and
resulted in a citation for (d) and (g) related to this rule. Please
refer to the Analyst Concerns Addressed section of this report
for additional reporting and any further corrective action plan.
R400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of eighteen updated service plans (USP) was not
documented. The report was due by 8/7/18, making it twenty-
one days late.
R400.12419 Initial service plan.
(1) The initial service plan, as required by R400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster parent.
Two of four initial service plans reviewed did not show clear
documentation of the specific child management plan to be
used for the respective child.
R400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of one open independent living youth records reviewed did
not show documentation the program statement was provided
the youth before placement.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency’s policies and procedures required by this
rule.
8

One of one open independent living youth records reviewed did
not show documentation a copy of the policies and procedures
were provided the youth.
R400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each youth who
ends independent living is provided with all of the following:
(b) A birth certificates.
(d) The youth’s funds, and personal property.
Two of two closed independent living youth records reviewed
did not show documentation that the youth was provided a birth
certificate or the youth’s funds and personal property.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
In three of six open foster home records and two of three closed
foster home records reviewed, various records did not show
consistent documentation of uploads of all forms, (i.e.
application, training logs, social work contacts, 3080 compliance
record, 3706, closing summaries) to the system.
In five of seven open foster child records reviewed, various
records did not show that all signed service plans, parent
agency treatment plan agreements, FTM DHS-1105, DHS-69
and or medical passport documentation was consistently
uploaded to MISACWIS.
ISEP 6.16 Relative Foster Parents (Commitment 52).
(a) When placing a child with a relative who has not been
previously licensed as a foster parent, DHHS shall:
(3) within 30 days, complete a home study determining whether
the relative should, upon completion of training and submission
of any other required documents, be licensed as a foster parent.
9

One of seven open foster child records reviewed, where this
rule was applicable, showed a home study(3130A) was not
completed with 30 days of the child’s 1/25/18 placement.
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Three of seven open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation the foster parent/ caregiver was provided the
medical passport at placement. The information was not
documented in MISACWIS.
One of these records was where a caregiver informed the
DCWL Analyst they did not receive the child’s medical passport.
This record did not show documentation the medical passport
was provided the caregiver at the time of placement on 1/25/18.
Three of seven open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that the medical passport was updated quarterly.
Two of seven open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that all available medical and or dental
information for the child was documented on the updated
medical passport.
Repeat Violations- Interim 2017.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Two of twenty-two service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of the birth parent’s signature.
10

Two of twenty-two service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of the youth’s signature.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2017.
ISEP 6.42 6.42 Visits, Between Siblings (Commitment 78).
(a) DHHS shall ensure that children in foster care who have
siblings in custody with whom they are not placed shall have at
least monthly visits with their siblings who are placed elsewhere
in DHHS foster care custody.
In one of seven open foster child records reviewed, where the
child was placed separately from his siblings, the record did not
show consistent monthly siblings visitation.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Policy FOM 722- Unannounced home visit
6H
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the
placement every quarter. This unannounced visit must be noted
in the social work contacts of the case service plan.
Two of seven open foster child records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of a quarterly unannounced visit.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2017.
Policy FOM 722- Foster care- Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
8C Agreement.
Signature: When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee
Of twenty-two service plans reviewed, five did not contain the
foster parent/caregiver’s signature.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2017.
11

Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
9
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report.
One of twenty-two updated service plans reviewed was six days
late, in that it had not yet been approved/signed within 14
calendar days of the report’s 8/8/18 completion date.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care Action Summary.
09C
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a case.
The foster care action summary is generated from SWSS FAJ.
The DHS worker must complete the DHS-69, Action Summary
(RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies will continue to use
the DHS-69, Action Summary template. This form also serves
as notice to the courts of changes in placements, parent's living
situation and the FC worker/agency, as identifying information is
indicated. The FC/JJ action summary meets licensing
requirements for replacement documentation (See FOM 722-
03) and in most cases, agency transfer and case closing
summary (see below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be
used for foster care transfer to adoption.
Which Cases/ When What does this mean
All foster care cases where there is:
2. Termination from foster care placement.
Six of six closed foster child records and of two of two closed
independent youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of a DHS-69 for the child’s/youth’s case closure.
Policy FOM Case Closure Discharge Document.
722.15
The caseworker must provide a copy of educational documents
social security card, birth certificate, and completed medical
passport to the birth parent or guardian at the time of case
closure.
Four of six closed child records reviewed, where the child was
returned to a parent or guardian, did no show documentation
the items identify in the standard were provided to the birth
parent or guardian.
12

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.1236 Borrowed home (1) (c) & (d).
The agency was apprised the date the evaluation and reevaluation were
reviewed/endorsed, and by whom shall be consistently and clearly documented.
R400.12327 Special evaluation(6)(a)
The agency was apprised its letter to the foster home that the completed special
evaluation is attached shall not be dated before the completion date of the special
evaluation.
R400.12420 Updated service plan((1)(e).
The agency was apprised when there is a change in placement, the USP shall
accurately reference the child’s adjustment to the correct placement.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12209 (1) Orientation and training.
The agency was advised having some type of orientation sheet/training log to
document this initial orientation and recording that orientation in the learning system
may aid it in showing clearer compliance to this rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
The first incident related to allegations that a foster mother choked a foster child,
leaving scratches and red marks on the child’s neck.
The agency completed an investigation which gave the history of the foster parent’s
behavior and a recommendation for revocation of the foster home license was
made.
The second incident related to allegations that a relative/foster mother was arguing
with her fifteen-year-old foster daughter and pinned the youth down and removed
the youth’s phone while at one location. he agency found the foster home in
violation of the foster home behavior management, foster parent qualification and
records check rules. Revocation of the foster home’s license was recommended.
The agency appeared to have acted appropriately related to these incidents and
adhered to Departmental timeframes related to the special evaluations. However,
the agency received rule violations related to Act 116, 722.120(3) as documented
earlier in this report.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
13

maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan related to the agency’s Interim Inspection, where it
received three rules, three ISEP and two policy violations. The agency was not
totally successful with that correction action plan. It received repeat citations this
inspection, in the area of ISEP 6.33 for Assessment and service plans, ISEP 6.49
for medical passports; 722.6H for unannounced home visit; and 722-8C for Foster
parent signatures on Parent Agency Treatment Plan Agreements. The agency also
receives more rule/standard citation this inspection. It is important to note that the
agency’s timeliness with report was significant. An area for more agency focus
appear to be on documentation and consistency in MISACWIS uploads.
BCAL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety and Concern Alert #1:
Concern:
 The children do not have adequate space in their bedroom.
Resolution:
 The space meets rule compliance. The foster parent moved the beds from side
to side and put in bunk beds and that freed up adequate space. Photos showing
the change were received and are on file.
Concern:
 Foster parent never received foster care payments for previous placements.
Previous placements were of three children.
 According to the foster parent, she has sought legal assistance regarding this
issue.
Resolution:
 The agency showed placement periods for each child referenced by the foster
parent; and payments to the foster parent with the the check number and
check date. The documentation showed no payments were missed.
Concern:
 Doesn’t receive the proper DOC, according to the current children’s level of care
required.
Resolution:
 The agency reported the foster parent receives the appropriate rate each child
qualifies for. The foster care worker even completed another DOC assessment
for the one child on 8/14/18; and the child’s DOC rate /Level was unchanged.
The foster parent is receiving the highest rate granted for each child bases on
each child’s needs.
14

Concern:
 Wasn’t informed about the children’s background prior to placement. A foster
child has behavior issues. The foster parent wasn’t informed of the other child
being a bedwetter.
Resolution:
 The agency reported it shared this information wit the foster parent. A review of
MISACWIS social work contacts showed documentation of background
information on each child being shared with the foster parent before placement;
and of medication being shared and what that medication was for, ie. anxiety/
depression and incontinence for the child the foster parent reported not being
aware was a bedwetter. The SED and DOC review with the foster parent
documents that behavior and past history information was discussed with the
foster parent.
 Social work contacts did not document whether the foster parent was provided
with all information required by R400.12417 for Foster parent information,
subrule (1)(d), (g). The agency received a citation for these subrules in addition
to the three other foster child records reported earlier in this report. Corrective
action plan required addressing all aspects cited pertaining to R400.12417.
Concern:
 The foster care worker doesn’t make required monthly visits.
Resolution:
 The agency reported the foster care worker completed all required monthly foster
home visits. A MISACWIS review by this consultant showed compliance in this
area.
Safety and Concern Alert #4:
Concern:
 The assigned worker failed to make required face-to-face contact with the birth
parent when the goal for the case was reunification. According to the birth
parent, the assigned worker only made one visit to her residence.
Resolution:
 The agency reported the child came into care on 10/10/16 and over fifty contacts
occurred with the birth mother prior to the 4/11/18 goal change to adoption. A
MISACWIS review by this consultant showed, more than one home visit occurred
with the birth parent in her residence, numerous contacts, inclusive of attempts,
and contacts with the birth parent when the birth parents resided with others.
There is no rule noncompliance.
15

Safety and Concern Alert #5:
Concern:
 The foster care worker hasn’t conducted any unannounced home visits, as
required with the relative caregivers.
Resolution:
 The agency reported the the foster worker made required unannounced home
visits. A MISACWIS review by this consultant showed compliance with
unannounced home visits to this caregiver’s home.
Concern:
 The relative caregivers do not have a medical passport for the children that are in
their care.
Resolution:
 The agency had no prior documentaton showing that the relative caregiver
received the medical passport at placement. The agency provided the medical
passport document to the foster parent on 8/22/18.
Concern:
 The family has a trampoline with no safety net.
Resolution:
 The foster parent refused to install a safety net because the youth was leaving
the home. The agency later reported the foster parent did not want the child
removed. The child was remaining in the home and a safety plan was being done
around supervision and the trampoline. The agency was working with the foster
parent on purchasing a safety net.
Concern:
 According to birth parent, she didn’t receive proper referrals according to plan
that was developed.(Ex: The referral for their psychological exam was received
late, so instead of completing the service in May, it’s just being completed.
Resolution:
 The agency reported the court did not order a psychlogical for the birth parent
until 6/26/18 or 6/28/18 ; the court was delayed in scheduling a dispositional
hearing on the case until then. A referral for section 8 housing occurred 5/10/18
and the psychological referral was attempted in late July, but was delayed due
issues with the provider. The psychological referral was executed on 8/1/18;
and the birth parents’ psychological assessments occurred 8/16/18. Case
16

documentation of these reporting was verified by this consultant. Service
referrals were completed for the birth parents within appropriate timeframes.
Safety and Concern Alert #6 and #6a:
Critical #6:
Concern:
 Water feature without an alarm/rescue equipment.
Analyst observed there was no alarm on the door that leads directly to the pool.
They do not have rescue equipment.
Resolution:
 The caregivers installed safety equipment on the pool, and an alarm on the door
leading to the pool on 8/15/18. The relative caregiver provided photo’s showing
the installations.
 Home furnishings aren’t properly maintained. Analyst observed torn screens on
the side door and patio door.
Resolution:
 The caregivers completed screen repair of the side door and patio door on
8/15/18. The relative caregiver provided photo’s showing the installations and
repairs.
During the consultant’s on-site visit, it was revealed the agency’s worker did not do a
face- to- face related to Alert #6. The worker spoke with the caregiver(s) and had
them to submit photos. The agency was apprised it is the Department’s expectation
that the agency made a face-to-face contact to the foster home/relative home related
to these Critical Alerts.
Concern #6a:
 The foster care worker isn’t making home visits and face-to-face contact with the
birth parent as required.
Resolution:
 The agency reported the foster care worker made required contacts with the birth
parents. A MISACWIS review by this consultant showed the foster child was
placed in foster care 6/26/17 and numerous face-to-face contacts occurred with
the birth parent. MISACWIS documents, showed the birth parent did not have
her own residence until sometime just prior to 5/16/18 when the worker visited
17

that home. Two unannounced parental home visits followed on 7/25/18 and
8/15/18. Compliance indicated, no further action required.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
August 30, 2018
